captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

MATT FARAH: The Dyno is the
primary way to measure how

much power a car is actually
putting to the ground.

Some cars come with lots of
advertised horsepower, but

also lots of unadvertised
drivetrain loss, meaning

anywhere from 10 to 30% of that
horsepower goes to waste
just spinning the car's own
transmission, axle, and wheels.

What's really important is how
much power and torque actually
propels us forward.

Although horsepower and torque
have been the tried and true

measurements of power since long
before I was alive, we

all had better get used to the
newest measurement of power in
the performance car handbook.
The kilowatt.

When a crazy person like Bill
Caswell calls me and says,

come down south, drive
my friend's E36,
it makes 400 kilowatts.

My first thought is, I don't
know what the hell that means.

So when I met up with EV West,
I asked them to come here to

DynoTech Motorsports, so we
could put their E36 on the

Dyno and find out what 400
kilowatts means in terms of
horsepower.
Let's go.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

342 horsepower and 850.4
pound feet of torque,
at 600 RPM Mp torque.
That's nice.

850 to the wheels, that's
like a Super Duty
with a tune on it.
That's crazy.
I want to drive it.

MICHAEL BREAM: It's a new way to
develop torque, and it was
interesting to us.
We're automotive enthusiasts.

We're not necessarily green
people, or hippies, or
anything like that.

We're racing the car, so it's
not like we did this because

we wanted to kind of build a
Prius or something like that.

We did it because we wanted
to develop 800
foot pounds of torque.

MATT FARAH: Even with a very
strong drag transmission, full

torque from this motor at zero
RPM will cause gearbox parts

to basically run away
from each other.

MICHAEL BREAM: With a car that
develops this much torque, it

gobbles up drivetrain
components.

We've lost a factory 5-speed
transmission, we've lost a

high-end clutch, we blew up an
M3 diff, and earlier today on

the Dyno, it looks like we
might've done some damage to

first gear and the
power glide.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

That's your 12-volt system, it
still has a regular 12-volt

system for the wipers and
all the other stuff.

These are your infrared internal
motor temperatures.

So this is actually, since you
can't but a sensor on the

moving part, we shoot an
infrared beam to it and
measure it that way.

You're kind of getting concerned
temperature is

around 240, your do not
exceed would be 320.
If you get above 240--
MATT FARAH: What do you do?

MICHAEL BREAM: Turn
on Fan 2, and just
drive it a little mellow.
They come down real quick.
Yeah, it recovers real quick.

MATT FARAH: So now
I can drive.
MICHAEL BREAM: Yep.
MATT FARAH: OK.
I can do this.
MICHAEL BREAM: All right.
Good luck, man.
MATT FARAH: No problem.
MICHAEL BREAM: We'll see you.

MATT FARAH: It's a big steering
wheel, though.
You ready, Tom?

I think we need one fan,
and then that,
and I'm getting gear.
And I think now I can drive.
Hey, there we go.
I'm off.
OK.

Then I think I-- yeah,
all right.
So this is very different.

First of all, everything says
I'm in a race car, here.

I'm sitting on the floor,
steering wheel's
huge and way up high.

I've got a net and some
harnesses, and I've got some

gauges and a lot of switches
and things going on.

So I don't really feel like I'm
in something that's meant

for economy or saving
the environment.

I feel like I'm in
something that is
designed for going fast.
So that's a good start.

Because if you're going to say,
hey, matt, come drive our

electric car, it better
be a [BLEEP]
fast electric car.

I've got manual steering and
manual brakes, so at 3,800

pounds, this is going to be
the heaviest car I've ever
driven with manual steering.

The funny thing is with these DC
motors, it's sort of like a
big diesel truck engine.

Big displacement,
but low revving.

You picture a Tesla roadster,
which redlines at 14,000 RPM,

this redlines at 4,100, so it's
very low-revving, but
it's got some grunt.

Some people say they don't like
electric cars because
they miss the sound.
There's sound here.
I've got, "mdrooo".
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
Look at that go!
Oh, my God.
Is that real?
Is that an accurate speed?

He said this thing's
GPS based.

If that was an accurate speed,
this car is way faster
than it lets on.

MICHAEL BREAM: To drive
this thing, it's just
a kick in the pants.
The torque just hits you.
It's instant.

You don't have to wait for
any boost to build up or
anything like that.

So if you like to kick out the
rear end and get the car

loose, it's actually
made for that.

So last summer at Pikes Peak, we
ran the electric class, and

we were the first car
for a street car,
so we won that class.

And for the whole electric
division, we got fourth place,

and I believe we were
51st overall.

Altitude doesn't affect
our car like it
affects all the gassers.

They're down about 20% on
horsepower at altitude and for

us, the electric motor just
ran the same as it
would at sea level.

MATT FARAH: I like this car,
though, because it makes weird
space noises.
Wooee!
Oh, what's the word.
It's deceptive.

When you've got sound, but not
the traditional engine noise.

When you have sort of a rubber
bandy tug, a shove
rather than a slam.
It's very weird.

You don't really notice how fast
you're going until it's
time to slow down.
I mean, look.
This is me.
Tons of torque.
Super cool.
Very, very clean build.
Very nice.

But at the same time, is
this something I want?

Do I want to see electric
race cars and
electric racing series?
I don't know.

It seems like it kind of defeats
the purpose of going

to the track if you're just
going to be going, just
hearing electric cars all day.
I do like not having to shift.

Just throw it into
second and go.

MICHAEL BREAM: So what my
partner, Matt Hauber, and I do

here at EV West is we really
try to be like a race
engineering firm.

We try to, kind of, do a lot of
the engineering, and front

load of the work, and develop
the car into a system that we
can repeat easily.

Now, at this point, it would be
really easy for us to build
another M3 E36.

I think the biggest challenge
with converting a car at this
stage is just money.

All the parts, all the
components are there.

The technology is
ready for this.

We just need a couple more guys
that are willing to spend

some money and kind of step
up and experiment
with stuff like this.

If the OEMs aren't going
to do it, it's
kind of on our shoulders.

MATT FARAH: EV West is a great
place to visualize the innards

of potential future engines,
pistons, heads, drive line,

cooling, the gas station,
the fuel.
It's a new chain of events.

But I'm still torn about whether
or not I like the idea
of an EV race car track car.

I mean, making it heavier
makes it worse.
There's no doubt about it.

Adding weight to it
makes it worse.

Now adding a ton of torque
certainly makes it fun, but

it's kind of the same thing as
driving an 800 horsepower, 900
horsepower GTR.

If this was just an M3 with a
gas motor and it weighed 2,200

pounds, I think I'd be having
a little more fun.

I think I need to go home and
think about whether or not
this is good.
And I'll get back to you.

What I like about EV West is
they aren't here to make

commuter cars or save
the planet.

They develop electric race
cars, and this M3 is
unquestionably a race car.

It's uncomfortable, it's got
heavy controls, it's hot,
loud, and rough.

It absolutely hates
going slow.

But it's not supposed to be
a model S. Race cars are

supposed to go as fast
as possible.

And this is, without question,
the fastest electric vehicle
I've ever driven.

As history has shown, racing is
the fastest way to improve

a car, and even lukewarm as I
am about electric cars in

general, hopefully EV West will
do the same with racing's

newest component in need of
development, the battery.
[THEME MUSIC]
[TIRES SQUEALING]

comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
The real problem, as with most EV issues, is that they don't have the 
battery technology needed yet. A semi truck must have long range, and a 
large output. A truck drivers NEEDS to be able to haul all day, every day; 
he can't stop every few hours to charge his batteries for an hour, not to 
mention the weight of any batteries big enough would cut into the cargo 
capacity....ever heard of axle-loading limits? It's even more so for large 
equipment. Productivity is absolutely key in heavy equipment. They spend 
tens of millions on large mining trucks and heavy; they need to to produce 
as much every day as possible. A vehicle that breaks down or needs to stop 
working a couple times every week for maintenance is an abomination. Having 
to stop and charge multiple times a day is the same. Switching batteries 
requires time and facilities that cost money, while a diesel truck can just 
fill up a 1,000 gallon tank of diesel in the morning and go all day.
  Yes, electric motors make a great deal of torque, but the energy storage 
is impossible with modern battery tech. That is why when they do use 
electric motors they store energy as diesel fuel, convert it with a big 
turbodiesel engine, and then send it to electric motors in the wheels. 
That's how most American locomotives work, and that's the way that the very 
biggest mining trucks works. For anything smaller, it's not worth the extra 
cost, weight and complexity of having to fit an engine AND electric motors 
into the vehicle. It's called "diesel-electric transmission".
In Europe, electric trains that take power off of an overhead line are most 
popular, but it's not so easy in the US. The US is much bigger, and 
therefor it would require us to pay to lay down much more line to cover all 
the main tracks. Second, transmission lines literally loose power over 
distance, so it would require huge inputs to have sufficient power at the 
end of a long line, and you have to keep that line powered 24/7, in case a 
train runs over it. The expense is enormous. Most American rail lines are 
less intensively used than European ones, so it would take long for the 
cost of electrifying to pay off. Rail has been more popular in Europe, 
because the distances are shorter (less track laying and maintainance 
costs), but particularly electric rail, because fuel has always been much 
more expensive in Europe. In the US, electric trains don't make sense. But 
I've gotten off topic now...

comments.text:
Its 340hp.. they shouldn't get too caught up in the 840ftlbs at 600rpm.. 
guys, that's 64hp   big deal.... any gas car can do that in the "right 
gear".   don't confuse engine torque with torque /force at the rear 
tires.   Certainly you need the beefier components because of the 340hp 
matched with a low reving engine . (vs a racer e36 with its near 8000rpm 
redline race engine which has about half the torque as the EV through the 
RPM ranges, so you just need a gear train set up for cars that have double 
the torque, like a viper or something)
to put this in perspective, this EV e36 makes 800ftlbs of torque, but no 
gear.  just a Diff gear of probably 2:1.  that's 1600ft-lbs of torque at 
the wheels.   if I have my moms mustang with 200ftlb of torque, through a 
8:1 1st gear, I make 1600ftlbs of torque.... same as the EV e36.   :)
The point is, the max hp is probably pretty wide with the EV.  with no 
gears it will be at a very low HP range at the top and at the bottom RPM.  
a simple 2 gear gear box would make the eV racer optimal for  many 
tracks.   its great to see this in the form its in, but still there is work 
to be done to make it competitive.   better batteries and a 2 speed gear 
box will be part of the answer of how it can be competitive to gas racers.﻿
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
+Devin Williams I don't understand your second question.  "In the lowest 
gear the car has, will you make the most torque at max torque or max 
horsepower?"    
Ill put it this way, there is the most amount of rear wheel torque in 1st 
gear at max torque.  But, not really.. actually you can do a clutch dump at 
max HP , releasing more torque from the engine and the KE of the rotating 
mass , to accelerate faster.  this is why drag racers dump the clutch at 
redline, or near max HP and not near max torque.    launch is an entirely 
different argument and is much more complicated.  look at 2nd gear and 
beyond.    you wouldn't want to accelerate in 2nd gear at max torque, when 
you could drop down a gear to 1st and be near max HP, and have 30% greater 
torque at the rear wheels, even though the engine torque is less...... this 
is due to the equations ive listed.
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
+Devin Williams  your first reply....... no  if your gears are limited , 
you have a fixed ability to accelerate based on the Power you make at the 
speed  where the two meet. if you have a excess of power at max power for 
the speed, you will continue to accelerate until the force generated equals 
the force it takes to achieve that speed.  very few cars can have a max 
speed that exceeds their top gear and max RPM.   if so, get some larger 
tires. :)
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
+zanick2 I mean the max torque you can possibly have at the wheels. EVER. 
ANY SPEED. I can not "forget about" what gear I am in if there is a limit 
on my gear ratios to choose from. In the lowest gear the car has, will you 
make the most torque at max torque or max horsepower?
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+zanick2 If your  gears are limited, you are going to use max engine Rpm 
for top speed, not Hp, because you do not need more power, simply to turn 
your wheels faster due to having low gear ratios
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+Devin Williams    "absolute"?? that makes no sense either.  a "given " 
speed, means , comparatively.  (e.g. at 100mph at 40mph, at 200mph, 
etc)     forget about accerative forces at any given gear, and think any 
given speed.   if you are at 60mph, you will select a gear to accelerate 
greatest , and that will be a gear that is closest to max HP, NOT max 
torque.   again, in the racing world, race cars rarely ever operate at max 
torque, ever!!    :)    they launch at max HP, they shift at max RPM to 
have an average power around max HP, etc etc etc, they never operate at max 
torque... and there is a reason for this as I have been 
describingacceleration = power/(mass / velocity)   this is a Newtonian 
identity , it cannot be argued and it states specifically, that 
acceleration is proportionally to power.
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
+Devin Williams   forget about the gears.... at any speed you are traveling 
at, you will always accelerate faster at max HP than at max torque.   you 
have to keep any comparison speed the same, or it is not a logical 
comparison.  it makes no sense.   "go faster" ??   max HP will allow for 
max vehicle speed.     max torque, again, will have nothing to do with top 
speed either.  it will be a product of force and speed (i.e. power).  you 
have to get your mind around the engine vs the rear wheel forces 
accelerating or producing accelerating or max force to create acceleration 
or top speed.   max hp is the max potential for a vehicle to hit its max 
speed.  if you hit max speed at max HP , it will go no faster.  you will 
not be able to get to any higher engine speed.   this could happen at 
1000rpm for a big diesel engine or 180000rpm for a gas engine.  max HP is 
where this point occurs  (not max torque, even though max torque ,in any 
gear ,is the greatest you can accelerate and produce force.  it doesn't 
matter, as it has to be at a particular relative speed!   key point!! think 
about this! )
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text: Im not talking about "at a given speed" im talking about absolute
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+zanick2
So you are saying in first gear, you accelerate faster at the horsepower 
peak then at the torque peak? Or vice versa, in final gear, you will go 
faster at max Hp speed than at max engine speed?
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+Devin Williams   no, the gear ratios don't have to be 'infinite", perfect, 
nor awesome at all!    and yes, because the laws of physics are pretty well 
known and set, I can say this with absolute confidence.   HP  IS 
proportional to acceleration.   there is no speed that any car would 
accelerate best, that is NOT at or near max HP.  Generally, max torque will 
never even be seen by most all cars , even with "not-perfect" gear 
ratios.   think of gear ratios as a HP efficiency directors.   they allow 
the car to select the right gear that is closest to max HP at ANY vehicle 
speed.  the closer you are there, the greater your acceleration at that 
particular, or ANY speed.   you are falling in the same trap as most that 
don't understand the forces that accelerate the car.   engine torque is 
completely irrelevant.    its rear wheel torque, that matters and that is 
dictated by max HP capabilities of the car.  its the reason that a viper 
comp coupe with a V-10 and 500hp / 500ftbs of torque, would accelerate the 
exact same as a Porsche GT3 with 500hp and 250ft-lbs of torque.     at the 
same weight these cars would accelerate the same at any vehicle speed..... 
why is that??? HP my friend!    both cars have the same HP at any speed and 
they accelerate at the same rate at any speed. (as long as they are the 
same weight, which in my racing series, they do and ......so, they do.  :) )
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
+zanick2 I understand what you are saying, it is rather simple, but you are 
making the assumption the vehicle in question has perfect, infinite, 
awesome, gear ratios. Simply not always the case, so can you really say Hp 
is directly proportionate to max acceleration and top speed?
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+Devin Williams  Now, your comment regarding weekend warriors...... as long 
as they keep their engines shifting near redline, they will be maximizing 
HP the best they can.    the only caveat is launch on a drag race.    
depending on lots of factors, and averaging out (or integrating) the area 
under the HP curve during a launch, will that decide what gear ratio would 
be optimal .  (factors include, optimal tire slip %, clutch slip, and many 
others)
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
+Devin Williams Devin, do you have an engineering degree?  I only ask so I 
can skew my responses to make the best possible sense?     for example, 
your point regarding max top speed , being brought about by top RPM , not 
max hp is very wrong.   in order to achieve max speed, its ALL ABOUT max HP 
, not max torque.   you have to wrap your head around the fact that rate of 
change of KE is power.  the greater that rate of change (i.e. acceleration) 
the more HP required.   as far as top speed goes, this is also power.   
power =mass x velocity.      the torque it takes to hit top speed, AGAIN , 
LIKE ACCELERATION, has NOTHING to do with engine torque.  the most amount 
of rear wheel torque at any vehicle speed will ALWAYS occur at max HP  , 
NOT max torque.  this is usually the hardest concept for new engineers to 
understand.   remember, torque at the wheels is synonomous to HP.  engine 
torque means almost nothing without RPM attached to it.
comments.author: zanick2

comments.text:
Not to mention not everyone has the knowledge/no how to a just gear ratios 
to match an engine....or predict what exactly people will be doing with 
it.  a weekend warrior might not have the luxury to adjust their gear 
ratios perfectly (or have enough ratios in the first place for them to be 
super close.....)
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
Every CVT has a max and min ratio,but they are infinitely variably in 
between those ratios. And acceleration and max pulling power are not 
necessarily the same. pulling 5 tons at 1mph may take less horsepower then 
1 ton at 50mphs. but it takes more torque at the wheels to pull the 5 tons 
regardless (and it helps to have that power come as early as possible), 
similar situation with CVT equipped tractor, actually a similar thing is 
done for top speed, giving it max Rpm for max top speed at highest gear 
ratio, not max Hp
comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+Devin Williams   now, as far as your gear ratio comment..... actually, 
yes, in each gear, the max acceleration will be at max torque of the 
engine, but that is still meaningless, as that is not at the power max, or 
the potential of the engine to accelerate the mass.   if your gears are not 
set up right, then yes, your condition can be true.   but in most all 
cases, peak torque is meaningless, and your max acceleration will occur at 
max HP at ANY vehicle speed.   this is why all race cars try and get their 
engines I the max HP range and keep I there.  its the reason for close 
ratio gear boxes and its the reason that you will more than likely never 
see max torque in a race car, as you will always be near max HP , which 
develops the most rear wheel torque at any same vehicle speed.    your CVT 
or IFV example, makes no sense, because if it was truly IFV Or CVT, the 
moment you floor it or engage the gear box, you would want the engine at 
max HP NOT max torque.  think of it this way .  acceleration = power/ (mass 
x velocity).  this means acceleration is always proportional to power!   
so, if you are in the correct gear (a gear low enough), you will always 
accelerate fastest if the RPM can be kept in the max HP range, because that 
is the highest level of acceleration the engine can produce for the mass it

(joule per second).   they are equivalent .there is no , joule-second.

A watt second (also watt-second, symbol W s or W·s) is a derived unit of 
energy equivalent to the joule.(Taylor & Thompson 2008, pp. 39–40, 53) The 
watt-second is the energy equivalent to the power of one watt sustained for 
one second. While the watt-second is equivalent to the joule in both units 
and meaning, there are some contexts in which the watt-second is used 
instead of joule.

comments.author: Michael G

comments.text:
+Bone Daddy There are many ways to determine the "efficiency" of a vehicle 
with an ICE. These types of motors put out a lot of heat, so by thermal 
efficiency standards, they are not very efficient. Mechanically, there is 
usually only about a 5% loss of energy in an ICE, due to friction and 
momentum, etc. When electricity is generated at a larger scale, even if a 
power plant used a gigantic ICE, the friction and thermal losses would 
account for a smaller portion of the total energy generated, due to the 
smaller relative surface area of the walls of a larger combustion chamber. 
Remember, heat is transferred most efficiently through conduction, which 
requires surface area. Combustion chamber volume increases a lot faster 
than wall surface area as diameter increases (2pi(r) vs pi(r^2)). 
Theoretically, larger electric motors (generators) are more efficient than 
smaller ones for the same reason. At the most basic, large power generation 
plants are more efficient than ICEs. You then get into power distribution 
and transmission and thats another issue altogether, but i'm not an 
electrical engineer. So.. to settle your argument, centralized power 
generation is more efficient, due to economies of scale and thermodynamics. 
I'm just trying to spread some info, and yes, I am a mechanical engineer, 
or actually I will be in a few months (certs take time).

comments.text:
Indeed, people have been killed by ICE cars long before EV were built. In 
fact, sound doesn't usually enter into it--people will often tell you they 
didn't *see* a car coming.
It's a bit worse these days with some people having their eyes glued to 
their smartphones or simply in their dream worlds because they've got their 
music on loud. Make no mistake, I love music too but I definitely try to 
pay attention to the world around me (especially once roads are involved).

Also, remember that blind people are not exactly running around carelessly 
in parking lots or across roads--they are rigidly following road rules.

Similarly, even if I was in a noisy truck and about to reverse out of a 
parking, and I saw a blind person clearly on his way to cutting my path, I 
would stop and let him continue. You never know: the guy might just hard of 
hearing or outright DEAF as well, you don't assume he can pinpoint where 
you're coming from and how fast you're travelling. If your lack of 
timeliness comes into question, just tell people it would have been a lot 
worse if you'd carelessly injured a handicapped person.

It's quite ironic that policy-makers want to help protect a few blind 
people from EVs but somehow they'll sanction wars where hundreds or 
thousands of people risk dying...

comments.author: George Harding

comments.text:
Because its bullshit. The 400kw statement anyway. This setup made peak 
torque of 850 ft-lbs at 600 rpm. In order to make 400kw at all, that peak 
would need to be at 2753 rpm. This is considering the 400kw statement to be 
gross (makes gross tq 1000) , so a 15% loss would make 340kW at the wheels. 
With horsepower peaking at 2350ish rpm, torque was already down to 760 
ftlbs. another clue: these motors have rated power figures that list the 
voltage and amperes current draw. The advertised rated HP linked to these 
parameters does not take into account motor efficiency....that is a really 
lame way to sell shit.

As far as motors go, electrics generally win performance-wise over ICE in 
almost every way. Right now the problem with electric is the power storage. 
Current battery technology *sucks* compared to the amount of energy in 
fossil fuel. I get the dislike for lack of engine noise, etc but the fact 
is, if energy storage improves enough (light weight, more power) then I 
believe we will reach a point to where if you want to win races you will 
need to be electric. Younger generations will probably even grow to love 
whatever sounds those cars make better than the old ICE powered vehicles.﻿

comments.author: Devin Williams

comments.text:
+Devin Williams fuel: alcohol, fossil, batteries is all the same. They are 
an energy storage mechanism. How that energy is applied is what matters and 
all combustion engines are *way* less efficient than an electrical motor 
(more moving parts, combustion losses, etc). Consider typical combustion 
engines can't even break 40% efficiency at their very best and are 
generally *much* worse whereas electric motors can go over 90% using 
current technology and are lighter. All electric needs is a superior energy 
storage mechanism and combustion will be dead (whether or not that will 
ever happen, I don't know).
